bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: IN THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF THE WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
Nick Mordevich, Plaintiff, vs. Joseph Jacoby, as Marshall of the above named District, Defendant. }
PETITION FOR A WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS. 2139
The plaintiff and petitioner above named shows to the Court that he is unlawfully restrained of his liberty by the above named defendant in this
I.

The petitioner and complainant is a citizen of the United States conducting the business of seine fisherman plying his vocation upon the waters of Puget Sound within the State of Washington, and has been so engaged for many years last past. He has a license and during all the time hereinafter shown had a license from the State Fish Commissioner of the State of Washington authorizing him to take fish during the year of 1912 in the waters of Puget Sound, said State.
II.

That between the first day of April and the 16th day of April, 1912, he with others similarly situated, was taking fish from the waters of said Sound at a point along the northerly beach of Hales' Passage, a stretch of water seperating Lummi Island from the main land in Whatcom County, said District. That the Lumni Indian Reservation borders Hales' passage on the northeast side and the fore shore of such reservation is washed by the ebb and flow of the tide and the beach exposed at low tide varies in width from a few feet to as much as eight hundred feet.

On or about the 16th day of April, 1912, petitioner was plying his vocation at fisherman, casting his seine and taking herring along the waters aforesaid and in order to operate his said seine he approached the shore to shallow water and one end of the seine was held by another person between the line of high tide and low tide while plaintiff himself extended said seine and cast it into deep water, bringing it in a semi-circle to connect both ends on the beach when said seine would be drawn and tied and the catch of fish taken to a receiving vessel anchored in deep water and there disposed of for shipment to market.
III.

That while so fishing the said defendant took possession of the complaint under a warrant charging him with unlawfully fishing upon the said Indian Reservation, took him before the Honorable A. L. Black, Jr. United States Commissioner sitting in Bellingham, Who pretended to hold a hearing, preliminary, for the purpose of inquiring whether the plaintiff had violated any law and charging the plaintiff with having returned to the said reservation after having been removed by the Indian Agent. That evidence was adduced before said Commissioner the material and substantial part of which evidence was to the effect that while this petitioner had been engaged in fishing in the manner aforesaid ant at a time when he was below the line of high tide at the place aforesaid, the Indian Agent or sub-agent had said to your petitioner that he was on the Indian Reservation and must cease fishing there and go away, and there was no other or additonal evidence or testimony material to the charge made against the petitioner or under the affidavit charging the offense or the warrant upon which your petitioner was apprehended. That by treaty between the Indian Tribes and the United States made the 2nd day of January, 1855, at Point Elliot, Washington Territory and proclaimed April 11, 1859, the Island called Chohohosen was reserved by the Indians for their exclusive use, said Island being defined and brodered as situated in the Lummi Reservation at the point of seperation of the mouths emptying respectively
onto Bellingham Bay and the gulf of Georgia.
IV

By Executive Order No.1301 issued November 22 1873, the boundaries of Lummi Indian Reservation were prescribed as beginning an the mouth of the Nooksack River, thence up the river to the ahe line between sectio 7 & 8 township 38 north range 2 East, thence west along said line to low water mark on the shore of the gulf of Georgia, thence southerly and easterly along the said shore with the meanders thereof, acros the western mouth of Lummi river and around Point Francis, thence nor easterly to the place of beginning.
V.

Your petitioner and complainant shows that upon the organization of the State of Washington and the adoption of the constitution of the State of Washington by said State, the said State be came the owner of all the shore lands lying between the line of ordinary high tide and ordinary low tide within the boundry of said State by virtue of its sovereignty and the United States had never patented any of the lands along the said Indian Reservation.
VI.

Your petitioner and complainant shows that at no time did he reside upon or intend to reside upon any shores of the said Indian Reservation and had never been upon said Reservation at any point nor above the line of high tide. He had never been removed from said Reservation and never returned to said Reservation with any intention or purpose whatever, except as aforesaid in the exercise of his rights as a fisherman under the license of the State of Washington.
VII.

That notwithstanding his rights as aforesaid the said United States Commissioner and the said United States Marshall have caused your petitioner's arrest, incarceration in jail and now restrains his liberty upon the pretended charge that he had been removed from the said Indian Reservation and had unlawfully returned thereto. That no probable cause exists for holding this petitioner to answer for the crime of having returnd to the said Reservation after having been removed therefrom nor for unlawfully being upon the said Reservation in the taking of fish
from the waters of Puget Sound in the manner and the time and place as aforesaid and all these things your petitioner is ready to verify.
WHEREFORE your petitioner asks that the Court grant to him the Writ of Habeas Corpus, that the illegality of his restriant be inquired into and upon the final hearing, he be discharged.
S.M. Bruce
State of Washington, County of Whatcom. } ss. Attorneys of Petitioner

Nick Mordevich being first duly sworn on oath deposes and says: That he is the petitioner named above, that he has read the foregoing complaint, knows the contents thereof and the statements therein set forth are true.
Nick Mordevich
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 20th day of April
C.E. Williams NOTARY PUBLIC residing at Bellingham, Washington.
